Buy without fear
First of all, the seller has a full 90-day refund policy, so you don't need to worry that you will get stuck with a problem phone
Having said that, replacing and setting up a phone is a pain, which we had to do
My girlfriend and I each bought one
For mine, everything was great except that I could not get visual voice mail to work, despite numerous calls to Verizon and Apple customer support
Verizon told me that it is not a Verizon phone, so that may be the problem
Each time someone called or left a voicemail, I would receive a text message of gibberish
I would have to call *86 to hear if I got a message
I ended up giving the phone to my son since he doesn't use voicemail
My girlfriend's phone had no problem with visual voicemail -- also through Verizon -- but she had a different issue
Callers could not be understood on 3-way calls, which her family is doing a lot of right now to settle her father's estate
All the phones get shipped with a screen protector over them
The technician in the Verizon store peeled ours off so that we could inspect the screen
He said protectors can hide scratches
In our case, the screens looked fine when we held them up to the light
From a certain angle, we could see a tiny blemish with the phone off,but it was imperceptiblewhen using the phone
You may want to inspect your screen carefully when getting the phone
In the end, we got two renewed phones for less than one phone's price at Verizon
Buying this renewed phone is well worth any time it takes to return it if something is off
Worth The Price For The Quality

Disappointing - it feels like I was harmed by an old friend
Purchasing a renewed cell phone involves 4 critical (and inseparable) buying decision components
The following will describe, in as much objective detail as is possible, my recent purchase of an iPhone XS Max from the Amazon Renewed Premium program
1 - Hardwarehttps://www
The exterior of the phone was clean and scratch-free
Battery Health = 88%
The configuration of the phone was a “quirky” and the screen flickered from time-to-time
Disappointed (I needed the phone and had already purchased another $65 of accessories), I agreed with the Apple TSR and she helped me annotate the precise reasons for her diagnosis
2 - Warranty and Related Seller AssurancesI contacted the main Amazon Prime number and described the issues (At this point, I was in possession of the phone for less than 20 hours)
Rep 1 – after describing the issues to the Rep and the Apple diagnosis, the Rep agreed with the Apple TSR and suggested I return the phone
Supervisor – agreed the phone should be returned and stated that the return policy allowed up to 180 days but said that 25 days after they received the unit was more normal
com returns from Mexico since 2015)
3 - Customer Service (pre & post purchase)Pre-Purchase: Went smoothly
00 – phone, $8
24 – shipping & handling and $88
46 for the import fees deposit)
35 and a 3-hour round trip drive to the nearest DHL office
4 – Overall Value of the iPhone PurchaseI securely packed the iPhone XS Max to assure it would arrive safely, and sent it via DHL at a cost of USD 95
Despite the claims that Amazon will reimburse me for shipping, I have been told by an Amazon Prime Rep that I can expect to be reimbursed no more than $20 for the return
35 loss on this purchase
I will not purchase another phone until I have received the full refund for this one
Buying a renewed phone has not been the experience I was hoping for

Summary Rating1 Star – Hardware (iPhone XS Max) – defective1 Star – Warranty and Relate Seller Assurances1 Star – Customer Service1 Star – Overall ValueAgain, when buying a renewed product, it is impossible to detach the actual product (hardware) from the other components of the purchase

Better than Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge
It replaces a Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge

Obviously the antenna in the Samsung was awful because I would use 30% of the battery traveling from Central Massachusetts to western Mass, a 50 mile trip but there would be spots where it couldn’t find a tower and the battery usage skyrocketed when that happened
This is not a problem with the iPhone, so the antenna must be way better, or whatever technology it is that’s different from Samsung, it’s better
I could never get through a day without needing to recharge the Galaxy
I use the phone a lot for listening to music (battery drain), Google searches, Instagram and Twitter

With the iPhone my usage has not changed if anything has increased due to the novelty of the new phone yet I have been able to get through every day (except the day of purchase when it was not fully charged out of the box) without charging the battery during the day
The iPhone, also doesn’t burn a hole in my pants pocket or heat other objects when it’s battery consumption is high
No such issue with the XS Max
I also don’t lose reception where I did traveling on the road to western Mass
Music and speakers: The speakers in the iPhone are head and shoulders above the Galaxy and sound much more professional or like they are bigger
The sound is rich and full bodied and I don’t mind listening to music on the phone
Copying music to the phone took (6) minutes as opposed to an hour compared to the Galaxy when I had to do that when the Galaxy was new
That’s over 3000 songs if anyone is counting
The music interface is iTunes which was a learning curve but a quick one
I liked the music player I had in the Galaxy better but I’m still learning iTunes
Music also sounds better on my car stereo coming out of the iPhone than it did from the Galaxy

I had noticed this when my son would play a song I had on my phone using his iPhone in my car, the quality was significantly better coming from his phone which I thought was strange, but the same phenomenon exists with my new iPhone and my car
I don’t have to touch my iPhone to send texts, play music etc
This is a huge advantage over the Galaxy S Voice which is supposed to do the same thing but I could never get it to work consistently or even at all
Facial Recognition versus Finger Print Scanner: The iPhone facial recognition wins again
The only app I have needing finger print recognition is my bank app, but I am still able to use it by typing the password in
All other apps I have use facial recognition, Amazon, Starbucks, and other apps needing credit card authorization
There are more facial recognition apps than finger print scanner ones
Facial Recognition works even in really low light like darkness
The iPhone is Faster period

My Starbucks app took 30 seconds to load on my Galaxy, on the iPhone it takes 5 seconds; that’s significantly faster especially when you’re in line at the drive thru!!!Maybe that’s not a fair comparison but it’s reality
Screen Resolution: Here theGalaxy has the win, hands down
The iPhone is close but it just can’t compete with the Galaxy screen colors and resolution
It’s not a big enough of a difference maker considering all of the iPhone wins so far
That and the iPhone XS Max screen is actually larger edge to edge than the Galaxy
Jury still out on this one
Keyboard or keyboard apps: Galaxy wins here
At least until I find a swipe able keyboard I like as much as the one I had on the Galaxy
Look and Feel:iPhone wins over Galaxy S7 Edge because I grew tired of the edge screen causing issues
Such as touching the edge just a little, and it was hard to know you were touching it, would make the screen appear unresponsive
Even though the iPhone has an edge to edge screen it does not suffer from this behavior probably due to the way it fits in my hand
I am just glad I don’t have to hit the screen 7 times before I get a response
Size and weight: the XS Max is the same size as the Galaxy S7 Edge and weighs about the same, I know not scientific but their weight is similar
As you can tell I like the iPhone a lot
Can’t believe I waited this long to switch
There was a time when I loved the Galaxybut that was when I first bought it

First experience with iPhone:  a very mixed bag, mostly positive

The renewed iPhone XS Max I purchased recently has been mostly a great performer with a few gotchas, mostly related to my inexperience with IOS but there are a couple of things you may want to be aware of generally:1
Originally I was looking at a renewed premium version of the iPhone XS Max with 256GB internal storage; the price was almost $60 more for the premium renewed version

The biggest difference I could see outside of the longer warranty was that the premium phone was guaranteed to have 90% or more of maximum battery capacity available while the mere renewed phone was guaranteed to have 80% or more
I chose to save $60 and roll the dice; it paid off:93% maximum capacity remaining

I have to admit, I was a little concerned when I opened the outer shipping box and saw that the box containing the phone had minimal bubble protection around it and was actually loose in the shipping box
However the phone box was solidly constructed and held the device securely in place
It was not an original Apple box so I didn't get the cool outer atmosphere of Jupiter phone image on the outside, nor was there an original Apple charger or earbuds included inside
Not to worry; there was a USB-C to lightning cable and a 30 watt fast charging adapter included (I'll take that over earbuds any day)
The gold-color phone itself was packaged in shrink-wrap front and back and, for all intents and purposes, looked like a brand new phone
As a long-time Android user who'd never owned anything above a mid-range smartphone, the XS Max is the second most impressive phone I've ever held in my hand
The glass front and back with stainless steel frame makes quite the quality statement
I saw no noticeable flaws or scratches on the phone, but I did cover it in a protective case and added a screen protector right away so I could've missed something very miniscule
But honestly when it came to actually putting the phone through the usual tasks, there wasn't much noticeable difference between the Apple and the Android machines
While the iPhone boasts a higher-resolution OLED display than the Samsung's Super AMOLED display, I still found myself preferring the Samsung's screen because of the extra
2 of screen area, an advantage made even more noticeable because of the iPhone's more rounded edges and at times annoying screen notch
Keep this in mind:I am a long-time Android user and this is my very first experience with an iPhone

Have to ask, though:how do you long-time iPhone users live without the ability to close all your apps with a single tap, close all your (Safari) browser tabs in the same way or live without a restart button plus having to press two buttons to turn your phone off?I'm adjusting but my heart goes out to all of you who've been long deprived of those little conveniences
If Apple made those tiny changes and cut the price of the iPhone 12 Mini in half, they'd own the smartphone space
It's here that I have to acknowledge the one huge advantage iPhones have over Android phones:long-term OS updates
Eight-year old Android phones do not get Android 12; they're stuck with 4
1 if memory serves me right
A dear friend who has owned an iPhone 6S Plus she purchased new when it was first released (recently replaced with an iPhone 11) updated that phone to IOS 14
6 just before she purchased her new one
Advantage Apple in a big way
So far, I have to say I'm very happy with this iPhone and, by extension, the seller and their description of the phone; both have exceeded my expectations
If this XS Max holds up, I don't see me buying another phone for at least five years or more
And despite my affinity for Samsung phones and the Android OS, that next phone will probably be an iPhone

I thought this phone was the perfect replacement for me since it had dual sim cards slots, a dedicated SD card slot and even under display fingerprint reader
Unfortunately the reception on both Freedom Mobile and Rogers Wireless is horrible, often switching to 3G when outside in Toronto
The fingerprint reader is pretty much useless and misses 3/4 of the time
Returning this thing and going back to using my Iphone 8 Plus which takes much better photos and lasts just as long on almost 1/2 the battery size
Anyone considering this should look into the Xiaomi Mi 9 for roughly the same price but with class-leading cameras

Upgrading from LG G3 to Samsung Galaxy A70 in ON, Canada
I have considered another LG but for price I would get min memory which could be the problem with all the new apps I am d/l with smart products
After a lengthy research, $$ vs Specs, I am now a first-time Samsung phone owner (i have owned a Samsung tablet for years just an FYI, so not a complete virgin)

I bought the Latin version SM-A705MN/DS which is completely compatible with Virgin Mobile (Bell), the phone was shipped very fast, but with a European super fast charge wall plug (it did include a cheapo conversion plug)
Another annoyance was the bluetooth connection to my VW Jetta which may be an older version of BT
The transfer of data was not smooth, I got all the apps but none of the app data (I guess LG and Samsung don't play well together)
I will have to get used to not being able to use Quick Memo feature, but with 128Gb/6Gb mem I think I will get used to it
This phone is very snappy,, great vivid colour, very fast charging and the battery lasts forever, I guess in comparison to a 2014 LG, I am very impressed
I will post an update if anything arises, so far so good

impressive feature set, decent cam front/back,  fairly good performance for a mid-teir device
This is going to be a review that highlights a few stand-out points (good and bad)
There are plenty of more detailed tech reviews out there so be my guest
I purchased this for a family member but i used it for a while before passing it on
What I LOVED1) price tag / value position
When you find this phone at around sub 400$ mark,you reallydo appreciate this phone
It's massive but it still holds OK one handed because its not that heavy
the screen is bright and ultra bright enough for outdoor use
despite what other reviews say, i think this screen is sufficient3) its a mid-teir chipsetbut actually , for one who doesnt play games much, this is not sluggish at all
love the massive flash capacity of 128gb too --- it kind of makes up for samsung's bloatware
Most of it is not used ---> install all google apps and disable the rest
The extra wide lens is handy for some situations which pixel phones cannot offer
it focuses and takes the shot instantly , similar performance as pixel2/3 performance imo
the camera app is much more richly featured than a simple pixel camera butin my honest opinion, these are allgimmicks
it takes good shots and it takes it quickly
This is anice bonus for me
this device already has a generous amount of flash but having that extra SD card slot helps alleviate the storage needs (i route all camera pics to the card whilst keeping internal flash for apps)
What I wish were better1) finger print sensor--- many reviews reported it doesnt work well under the screen
I found this very weird

It seems to work PERFECT with my thumb but with another person's thumb, it doesnt work AT ALL (???)I had to resort to face recognition for now until i figure this one out2) samsung bloat -- theres a tonne of bloat on samsung phones
i ended up disabling a lot of it especially the launcher
i dont love it at all
you cant really remove the software since it's baked into the firmware but the 128gb flash makes up for that
a typical pixel phone comes with 64 gb
this phone heats up quickand its warmer than other devices i've used
I'm not sure why but it is noticeable
so what other options are there?well there is samsung A50 too(at the time of writing, the A51 and A71 are the most current A-series phones but theyre just priced too high)
If i'm going to be totally honest here,i think if you can find a pixel2XL with 128gb flash, at under 400$, then you are better off with that especially because of the camera performance
I'm going to recommend this device if you really need the extra wide lens, the SD card, and nicer larger screen real estate

Before I write my review, I'd like to list a couple things about the phone which aren't included in the Amazon description:1
I prefer mid-range unlocked vanilla android phones that aren't too expensive to replace -> And that's exactly what this is
The screen is amazing!I came from a 1080p phone, and I was expecting this elongated 720p screen to look noticably worse
It really doesn't!It's crisp, clear, and the small bezels are quite nice
If you don't like the way the display wraps around the front camera, you can enable a gesture in the settings to disable that
The camera is good, and it even includes facemoji!The battery is excellent
The lowish resolution screen and low-power processor probably help this
The phone runs pretty much stock Android 8
The only changes I've noticed are a clear apps button on the recent apps screen and a new battery saving mode called extreme something-or-other
I haven't tried it
I've only had it for 2 days, though, so I'll be sure to come back and change the review if I run into any major problems
45 day break in EDIT : Listen .. if you're a parent , senior, smart teenager, this phone is great.
So far, Ihave gone through four generations of Blu phones
Out of all the budget smartphones I have ever owned, this one surpasses my expectations by far
The operating system itself is robust
The phone itself is made of quality materials, and the notch display - although a little bit gimmicky, is very effective after time
In the world of cases, you will be disappointed that the aftermarket appears to have not one single case available for this phone as of the 1st of January 2019
So what I have done is left the phone in its silicone case and it looks wonderful
If you want to make an amazing gift to your parents or grandparents and bring them into the smartphone community, this is a wonderful way to begin at all
The ease of the operating system, the speed of the processor, and the build quality of this phone are all very nice
Now as for the the sound quality - coming from the twin rear speakers: it is above-average
I cannot speak on the fingerprint reader as I find any security on my phone obtrusive
The pictures that the camera produces are on par with any average smartphone
It is almost unbelievable that you get this much phone for the money
And I read a review about the operating system
In all my years as a tech guy even in the army, this device is worth every penny and I stand by my review 100%I do not work for Blu , I do not get paid or compensated for anything
Oh did I mention that the battery lasts all day long and then some, and I'm a super user 😋😋😋
Edit : so it's been about 45 days with the phone
I keep reading the highest rated comment about blu not upgrading their operating system
I've also read comments that say that the hardware messes up the experience
I'm 40 years old, middle class, I use the phone more than a regular person
If you don't like it, you can return it as well, what do you have to lose??Also as of the last week you can buy an extremely nice case to fit this phone
Don't believe the other headlines, especially the one about Wi-Fi
That is definitely not a phone issue
Not everyone is going to have a great experience - but I would say for the most part these phones perform excellent
After 45 days I still grade this phone A

My 5th BLU phone.  .  .  Better Than Some

The hard part about BLU phones is that there are so many being released over the course of a year that you never know if you're going to get a quality build where they hit the sweet spot, or a short-lived piece of garbage
So far, so good with this one
Bear in mind this is an early, quick review (I've had this phone a week) but thusfar I've had absolutely zero issues with it
The processor is snappy, the screen is exceptionally bright, and the Android Nougat build is far better than Marshmellow
Battery life has been absurdly good and long-lasting
I replace my BLU phone approximately every 8-14 months due to physical damage and some have held up better than others
We'll see how we do this time around
Also of note I have had zero issues with connecting to Xfinity Wi-Fi here in California and my AT&T service is excellent with this phone

SIM slot headaches.....
The SIM1 slot is a microsim only slot, your carrier may refuse to activate a nanosim in that slot that is fitted in with a nanosim to microsim adapter
Mine did!The SIM2 slot is for a nanosim OR an SD card
You cannot have both at the same time!I had originally activated the phone with a nanosim in SIM2
I needed to move my nanosim over to SIM1 (via an adapter) and put the micro SD card in SIM2
Looks like either I have to return it, see if I can buy a microsim from my carrier without losing my grandfathered in better cost plan, or change carriers

I bought this phone in April of 2019 to replace a Vivo XL 2 started to have a battery issues as well as network connection problems after 2 years

I ordered a replacement SIM from T-Mobile to use with this new phone to be sure that the network issues I had with the old phone were not SIM related (SIM that I had was 3 years old, good idea to replace it with a new phone)
It keeps dropping the network and the SIM settings menu grays out in the phone settings
I have to reboot the phone, leave it powered off for 10 minutes, power it on and I have working network for another 30 minutes

Realistic expectations of the XL4
I've had the BLU XL4 for a week and everything got transferred over seamlessly and easily from my Blu XL3
T-mobile service worked right away, no setup necessary, as did voicemail and tethering (hotspot)
I'll compare the XL4 to the XL3
The notification tones and touchscreen sounds, as noted by others, are very soft
Even if the preview of sounds are loud when you test them, the actual notification sounds are soft
Takes a bit getting used to because the XL3 was loud for ALL sounds
Already noted in other reviews
Again takes a bit getting used to because the XL3 had it
I tried to install a 3rd party app to control it, and the app kept crashing which caused my fingerprint sensor to malfunction
So I gave up on that

I had tried to install a couple 3rd party apps to make different notification sounds and lights for the the XL3, and it ended up permanently eliminating the notification sounds altogether for a bunch of apps
I didn't feel like doing a factory reset so I just lived with it
So it looks like these BLU phones do not react well to 3rd party apps trying to control the sounds and lights
You've been warned
I did not try to mess with the default notification sounds on the XL4 because I suspect they'll behave the same way
Not worth potentially messing up all the sounds and having to do a factory reset
So now I have the default sounds & alarms for everything, and they work well
Those who like customized sounds and alarms on their phones will be very frustrated by this problem
I'm not entirely sure this is a BLU or Android-specific problem, but I'm leaning towards BLU problem
I'm not a heavy camera user, just want to take clear pictures in decent light which it does
I do like the Camera Zoom FX app better than the stock camera app because it focuses better before each shot
Serious camera enthusiasts will probably have more opinions
The BLU specs say the XL4 supports 802
This is incorrect
It does not support 802
So if your home wifi is on 802
You can't see the protocol setting on your phone
You have to use a desktop/laptop to see it after you've connected to wifi, click on the wifi name, properties, and it will show you which 802
11 protocol
I've taken my laptop to the gym and verified they used 802
So if your XL4 is not connecting to wifi even after rebooting everything, use a laptop to verify it's not on 802
See attached screenshots of checking Wifi protocol on your computer to verify it is on 802
It's great so far because it's a new phone
Hope it will last more than a year
My XL3's battery started dying around the 8 month mark
Removing it from the charger when at 100% at night would result in about 75% battery in the morning (25% loss overnight)
I always had to re-charge it once during the day
The XL4 only loses 5% overnight so far, and is over 60% at the end of the day
That's the main reason I got the XL4 - the battery
So far so good
I have it connected to my Mi Band 2 fitness band so all my phone calls/texts, notifications and alarms ring my band
Very good so far, as was my XL3
Love the big screen
The resolution is okay for my needs, it looks like my XL3 screen that got zoomed in a bit so not as crisp
Makes sense because they're both 720p

I'm pleased to report that the XL4 screen does not turn on randomly like the XL3!Could never figure it out on the XL3 (turned on least 20 times a day for no reason at all), but the XL4 screen never turns on unexpectedly running the exact same apps
This is due to Android's Doze program that is on every Android phone after Android 6
0 that is supposed to save battery by shutting down processes when the screen is off
I finally solved this problem by enabling developer mode, and running an ADB shell command to disable Doze (can't disable just from phone settings)
Notification and alarms are perfect now, same as my really Android 6
Several other reviewers of the XL4 have noted the notification and alarm problem so I thought I would detail the solution here
Keep in mind it's an ANDROID problem, not a BLU problem
iPhone Doppelganger for Fractional Price
The BLU VIVO XL4 is a great value phone
Several peers commented on it looking like an iPhone from afar

For me, moving from $30 AT&T special ZTE phone, this thing is powerful

I have run Pandora, Google Maps, and web browsed at the same time - didn't crash
This phone also fits my very large hand; the trend seems to have capped how big a smartphone can get, these days

It has Amazon and Prime Video apps installed, witch I've watched a few videos stuck on a train - worked flawlessly

Very little complaints after about 3 months of use, so far

So far, a great value phone and would consider a BLU phone again in the future

Perfect Replacement for My "Dumb" Smartphone
I have to watch my pennies
A workhorse phone
But the battery had worn out pretty much, so I went hunting for a truly smart smart phone
The Blu Vivo XL4 caught my eye and I spent quite a lot of time reading reviews both good and bad and examining all the specifications

I have a decent background in tech and I realized that the more technical complaints that people had were not things that affected me, such as automatic updates to Android versions people said never happened (note that my phone updated the version automatically the first day I turned it on)
I'm EXTREMELY happy with the phone
It has decent storage space and memory, plus it can handle my 128 gig micro SD where all my music is stored
My friends own far more expensive phones that don't do half as much as the Vivo
Screen resolution may sound a bit low, but I've owned tablets with 2 million pixel density and yes, that resolution is astoundingly good

One of the things that was a 'value add' for me was the superb packaging and extras that came with the phone: a decent set of ear buds, 2 cases (one clear, the other with Blu's trademark expressionist design), two types of screen protector (with a gorilla glass screen these are hardly needed), very efficient charging plug and USB cord and a cleaning cloth
One thing that some think of as a drawback is that the battery is permanently installed
But my old phone's battery chugged along for five years, so if the Vivo's lasts even half that long, I consider this a non-issue
Then watch one of the many YouTube videos on how to install both items
My kit cost me around $5 - a drop in the bucket
If you don't plan on having extra storage you can by-pass this suggestion since the phone itself has plenty of storage
This was my first unlocked phone purchase and I was pleasantly surprised to see that the bloatware was minimal
I plan to stick with this brand for any phone I buy in the future

This phone is wonky
I really wanted to like this phone
The aesthetics of the phone are beautiful but the inner working not so much
The first issue happened a month after it was too late to return the phone
The battery would discharge within a day, without any usage at all on my part
I got in touch with Blu customer service and they reset the phone
Again the phone and battery seemed to be normal
Then one morning at 6 amthe phone starts pinging with arriving messages and texts, despite the fact that I had set it on quiet hours
When I checked the settings, the phone was set on Eastern Standard Time, not Pacific Daylight, the zone where I live
I tried a manual reset but it would not take
A few days later the phone reset itself to the correct time zone
Next issue occured last night when I tried to send texts but they would not go through
I could receive texts and phone calls, but not send texts
So I called Blu support again and they said I had to send them the phone and that it would take 10-15 days where they would repair it, replace it, or possibly offer me a new model
This does not work for me as I need a reliable phone and am wondering what will happen next?$175

I had transitioned to Mint Mobile service last July
I could not make any calls from the house

I had concluded that Mint Mobile had poor service, and that I had to purchase a phone with wifi calling to at least get something out of my Mint Mobile commitment
I purchased a Google Pixel 4a
I inserted the SIM into the Pixel 4a and powered it up
Before I even turned on the wifi calling feature I had two of five bars--and full calling capability from anywhere in my house
I guess it wasn't the Mint Mobile service
Compared to the Pixel 4a, the BLU screen resolution and response is poor

Bad warranty, bad customer service, new phone started having problems after 2-3 months
I got this new phone last July
It was working fine for maybe 1-2 months and then weird things started happening
My phone would not ring
People who called me said that their calls would immediately go to voice mail
These problems were intermitten
Never knew if my phone was not working until somebody told me
I first contacted my phone provider to see if it was a network issue
I followed what they told me to do to troubleshoot
Then when they said it wasn't a network issue, I contacted BLU and they asked me to do a factory reset
I still had the same problem
Only this time, I knew it probably was the phone because when I did a restart of the phone, I would get the texts that I didn't get
I contacted BLU regarding their warranty and I was told I was going to have to send the phone back
I thought they were going to replace the phone but they said they have to see what's wrong with the phone first
Their turn around time they said is about 15 business days so that meant I wouldn't have a phone maybe for a month adding shipping time
This time they said they were going to replace my phone but again they want me to send my old phone back before I get the new phone
I told them that that means I will not have a phone again for at least a month and in light of current virus situation, it's really important for me to have a phone
And I even asked to talk to a supervisor, but she said sorry this is our policy
And that was it
They did send m e a return label but it was only good for 48 hrs
If you're buying from Blu, and you will need repairs, this is what you will have to deal with
I'm sure if it's just this model that sucks because my first phone was a Blu phone and I didn't have any problems with that
But with this model, I had problems within less than 6 months of using it
So I have returned the original phone I ordered for the second time and this time for a replacement
But unfortunately the replacement had the same problems as the original, and worse
They replaced my phone with a G60 which is supposedly an upgrade to the Vivo Xl4 which they said is no longer available

I found this one slower when downloading an app from Google play, it had a removable battery which probably explains why the recharge takes longer than the other model, and I think the battery lasts shorter than the other one too
It only came with 4 ringtones while the other one had about 12 or more ringtones to choose from
I called customer service and first they said I had to do a factory reset
I did but that didn't seem to fix the problem
So now they want me to send the phone back again to them for a repair or replacement
I asked them if they could replace it with another model or with the original model that I purchased and they said they couldn't do that, that's not what their policy says
I even talked to a supervisor but he said he can't do anything either
So it doesn't look like Blu is flexible about their policies and not very customer oriented
Because otherwise they would have been able to help me
In the final analysis, my conclusion or guess is that perhaps the Blu operating system is not compatible with Tmobile
So I would caution you if you have T-mobile as a phone provider for purchasing a Blu phone
And as I said before, they are sticklers to their policies so they really go by the book
But there are always exceptions to the rule
After having experienced returning my phone twice and having to wait one month each time, you would think they would be flexible on their policies but no they're not

Good Entry Level Phone
After using the phone extensively I have tested it out and found that for a inexpensive entry level phone this is a good phone to purchase
Firstly due to the higher internal hardware profile such as the eight core processor, the battery life of the phone is rather weak
Secondly and most importantly the sound profile of this phone is extremely lackluster
The fingerprint reader located on the back of the unit functions quite well
Camera is good but not great
Phone calls are of good clear quality and with the carrier I use I get no call noise or bleed over
The operating system on the phone I purchased was 8
1 and is a generalized version of Android with some BLU modifications
Over all the phone's specs are wonderful with extra storage, better than average RAM and a speedy processor that holds up to higher resource hogging apps and programs
But if your looking for a inexpensive phone that looks good and not planning on or needing solid sound, this phone is more than enough to satisfy the entry level user

I would recommend this phone for students, your children, or budget conscious consumers but would recommend that people with hearing issues to spend more money and getting a higher end model that can produce appropriate levels of sounds

In Comparison with Samsung

I just switched from a Samsung phone, and regardless of which models had best resolution/camera/other features that phones are normally ranked on, the Moto G7 Plus has these advantages:* Built in shake-to-turn on flashlight
Can't live without this feature*Advanced Bluetooth stereo options
The Samsung would get stuck in phone call audio quality after receiving a call while streaming music and would have to be disconnected and re-paired to fix*Always-on fingerprint sensor
The fingerprint app in the Samsung would crash every few days, necessitating a phone reset
These might seem like minor issues, but were a huge quality of life improvement and are honestly worth more to me than picture quality or processor speed (didn't even look at those for comparison)

Happy with my 2nd Moto G7+!
This is the 4th G7+ our family has bought

I had to replace mine because within 2 days I dropped it in water for at least 5 seconds (sat in rice 24 hours then worked well!) Then I dropped it face down, with Spigen case on it) on concrete from about 3 ft and the glass totally shattered (need a better case and glass protector!) I was going to upgrade to the G8 but didn't want to spend anymore on it due to my carelessness last week!Anyway at under $120 on Amazon I decided to get another G7+ because I saw that the model has changed somewhat
This one is great, easy to change out my T-Mobile SIM card and get it going easily
Battery life is similar to my last G7+ and is not as good as my older Moto G5, but I have the ability to charge daily and the turbo charger works quickly, so it's not much of a problem
I put on my old Spigen Case which wasfor the older circular back camera
It works with this newer oval camera, but does not fit perfectly, so I'm hoping a new case is produced quickly
I saw tmobile sells one for the Revvlry +made by Otterbox for $30 but I've never paid that much for a case, so I'm still deciding on that
Since I'm fairly careless with my phone, I probably should look into a better case!I feel like the camera on this new one is a bit better
Pictures seem more clear, so I'm happy with that
All in all, we are happy with our Moto G7+ phones
They do all that we need to do with them, they are budget friendly, and they work well with T-Mobile
Replaced A Moto G6 . . . .
My Moto G6 wasn't holding a charge as long as it used to, and sometimes it was difficult to get it to turn on, so I started looking for a new phone
No need to call T-Mobile about anything
The G7 does seem like an upgrade, but I really don't see that much difference in it from the G6
I think it has better speaker sound and a better camera, although I haven't used the camera yet, since I rarely use cell phone cameras
I was looking for another phone like that, but the only one was way too expensive
After getting the G7, I realized it was laughable to even search for such a phone, since I could easily download every Amazon app I wanted--Kindle, music, video, Alexa, etc
A charge lasts me for days, but then I turn off the phone for so many hours a day, and don't usually watch videos
It also charges faster than any cell phone I have ever used
Finding a case for the phone was no problem, although apparently it was at one time
I got the MagicSky Moto G7 Case,Moto G7 Plus Wallet Case, with the pink trees and butterflies

BEWARE!!!  This cellphone eats sd cards.
I have only been using it for about 4 weeks and evrything is working just fine
There is one major isuue
It eats sd cards
I have used more sd cards in cellphones than I can remember and have never experienced this before
I had already read a review that mentioned this issue and was extremely careful when placing the sd card in the tray and very carefully pushed the tray in
When I checked the portable storage ,sd card, it did not show any installed
I reopened the tray and it was gone, it disappeared into the phone
I took the tray out and the sd card was missing
I then turned the phone so that the tray opening was facing down and shook it figuring that it waould fall out but it did not
I then placed a second sd card into the tray that I had laying around, although it had much less memory, and again carefully pushed it in and fortunately it stayed in the tray and was recognized
The first sd card that was purchased specifically for this phone and eaten by the phone was 64 gb, the second was only 16 gb
Despite there being a sd card lost within the phone it fortunately is functioning just fine, so far
I now have a fraction of sd storage that I wanted and needed and have a sd card somewhere inside that will not come out, that cannot be good
I would like to remove the smaller installed 16 gb card and replace it with a larger 64 gb card but am afraid to

What will happen if it eats another sd card?Will it still function with 2 lost sd cards inside of it?Again I have installed MANY sd cards in cellphones over more years and have never had this happen before
Apparently this phone has a major flaw in the design of the sd card tray
Even being aware or this issue and being extremely carefull and experienced it can still happen
Just greatt for the price and quality.

Update edit a year later
I've replaced batteries in half a dozen cellphones before so I thought no big deal
Pry the screen off very carefully
Not just carefully, very carefully
In spite of the online instructions to do so, do not remove the connector for the screen, it's really difficult to reinstall, and there's no need
Obviously disconnect the connector for the battery and use heat or alcohol to aid in removing the battery
You may need adhesive to reattach the screen, it doesn't just snap or

A nice cheap-ish LineageOS-compatible phone
There's an unlock process on Motorola's website that entails using fastboot to pull OEM info from the phone, providing that to Motorola, and they then email you an unlock key

Full instructions can be found on LineageOS' website (search online for LineageOS lake - lake being the codename for this device), though I'll note I had to add an extra step: the final 'fastboot oem unlock KEY' command complained about needing to enable bootloader unlocking in Settings, so I needed to boot the phone normally, then connect to WiFi before I could change that particular setting (after which I was able to reboot back into the bootloader and run the unlock command)
Seems to run pretty smoothly with LineageOS 18
1 (Android 11)
It's only been running for a couple days, but battery life, performance, screen quality, and camera quality all seem to be pretty good, especially considering the price tag
None of the USB ports (type A or type C) on my laptop did the trick with any of the cables under Windows or Linux (openSUSE); thankfully it was more cooperative with my work Macbook's docking station
The LineageOS install instructions mentioned this for this particular device, but it was definitely weird how thoroughly uncooperative it was
Once the phone's booted (either normally or into recovery) the USB connection is a lot more reliable

Even so much as setting it down on a slightly uneven surface will result in it sliding around - in one case, off a work surface and onto a linoleum floor (which thankfully didn't result in any noticeable damage, though it somehow caused the phone to reboot)
The bootloader unlock process is needlessly complex (per above), but it at least exists and it did (with some finagling) work, so I can't complain too much there
Given the pricetag, the LineageOS compatibility, and being available in a pinch, I'm glad I bought it
Should tide me over until my Astro Slide 5G finally arrives

The price was phenomenal, about $122 before tax

The phone itself works fine
Fingerprint reader easy to use, screen is pretty good (though has a bluish/cool hue, a bit different than my iPhone's warm screen), and it is fast enough for most applications
I wouldn't recommend for this gaming (of course), but for <$150, if you need a basic smartphone that can run some apps and make phone calls, this will fit the bill
Pair this with a cheap mobile plan (prepaid or Mint mobile), and you have a very affordable phone for low-to-medium duty uses

No case available anywhere on the internet.  Is it really US phone?
As the headline indicated, I cannot find a case for this exact model phone
Any case shown online for this model has cutouts that will not fit the different shape of the camera lenses on the back, which is oblong, not round
I suppose one could try to buy a case and try to modify it by cutting, but once the case is not actually for this exact model phone, you can’t know whether the sizes will match
The phone without a case is extremely thin and thus, slippery
It seems odd to indicate that this is a US phone but have nearly exclusively foreign links to it
Perhaps a clue is that my previous “unlocked” Moto g6 was an international version and thus the warranty could not be applied when it bricked

I suspect that unlocking is more universal in the rest of the world compared to the US, where phone companies are still infatuated with selling phones at a discount on contracts that make it difficult to change providers

Snappy, Stable Phone
Everyone has an opinion, so here's mine: For the money, this is a fantastic phone for the stability, features, and updates you get
It's not the latest greatest, but it has great performance and camera resolutions that exceed my needs and has no issues with locking up on my goofy apps required by work, etc
You will need a case however, since it is thin, smooth, and slick!Also, I have never needed more battery than it has, but if you're a big time media person or gamer - this phone is not for you
Battery lasts me all day with plenty to spare, BUT All I do is make phone calls, use it as a GPS/maps, email, work orders, etc
I tried using YouTube through bluetooth car audio to listen to some podcasts one day, although it did make it, I had 12% left when I got home at 7pm
So it will play plenty of games and video - just want to be plugged in for it probably, or have the quick charger along, because man does it charge QUICK! Big plus

I needed a replacement phone, due to a swollen battery on my Huawei Mate SE (I discovered overcharging a cell battery increases gasses in the battery from a phone tech, so don't leave your phone constantly charging, folks)
I had debated spending $500 or more for a high end phone, but learned a lot of the technology in more expensive phones is dedicated to photo-taking technology
The phone comes with the described accessories- USB-C cord, screen protector, charging brick, and a very thin, rubberized case
The phone has a massive 128 gig internal storage capacity
Out of the box, the phone was charged to about 56%, and was loaded with Android version 9
The on speaker at the bottom is very loud
The phone seems only able to pick-up the 2
5 Ghz channel on your wireless network
Exporting all my apps and settings from my old phone to the P-30 was almost seamless, using Huawei's Phone Clone app (you can obtain it in the Google Play Store, for your old phone)
By default, ALL your apps will be displayed over multiple screens
Ease of use is relative
I enabled fingerprint and facial recognition to unlock the phone
There is a notch at the top of the phone, which can be hidden via settings
I find the camera much faster than my old phone, and more variety in how to take take photos
There's no native internet calling feature, but there's 3rd party apps that support that (but you will be issued a new phone number)
Scrolling is fast and smooth
I found one little quirk: When viewing Youtube, the video is about 20% smaller than the screen
There's plenty more features to be discovered, but at this price point, this phone is a winner
My Consumer Cellular SIM Card would not fit in the carrier in the card slot.

A little sluggish, but otherwise really solid
I've used a 2016 Google Pixel for the past couple years and needed to upgrade when that phone recently died
The P30 lite has a gorgeous screen with a tiny notch at the top - which I did not find distracting
The software is not stock android, but generally looked beautiful, functioned well, and had no bad habits
The software operates well and does a lot of thoughtful things that I appreciate
The phone has a suite of built-in apps that you can delete, but they will only re-install themselves at the next Google Play update
I don't know why phone makers still do this in 2019
This is more of a nitpick though
What isn't a nitpick is the general sluggishness feeling of the phone
It feels slower than my 3 year old Pixel
Opening and closing of windows, zooming in on images, and just general operation feel less snappy than I would expect them to
Most people won't find this offensive, but if you're coming from a more powerful phone - even an older one - you'll notice it immediately
For $270 its a great buy and for the price it would ordinarily be a five star phone
However given the alternatives, I'm afraid I have to ding it a star for the lack of speed

Galaxy A10e Tracfone Smartphone
I replaced my Tracfone because I wanted more internal memory
It was on sale Black Friday and I actually got it for $40 with a Whole Foods $10 credit
My old phone was a J3 and was fine, but 16GB of memory was having me deleting apps to add anything
Both phones have a microSD slot, but not many apps can go on it
You have to download the app, go into settings-apps-storage and see if it gives you the option to transfer it to the SD, if not- it has to stay on the main internal memory

You can put all of your photos/videos on the SD, which can eat up a lot of memory, but IMHO all cell phones should have at least 64GB of internal memory with all that is required for apps!Back to the phone- I think it is a perfect size, can easily fit into a pocket and natural in the hand
I also need a smaller phone because I am a cyclist and a larger phone wouldn't fit in my carry bag
It is slightly narrower than the J3, but longer
It has a very clear screen and has a touch home key- not a push button
I always turned on my J3 with this home key, so that is something to get used to

The selfie camera hole leaves a weird dip in the video screen @ the top of the phone, but in some apps (like Candy Crush) they square it off under that dip- it takes away from the overall size of what you are seeing, but then doesn't distract
It is a fast phone that does everything well
I have a minimalist case that keeps the thinness of the phone, which is important to me

Even with paying extra through the year for more texts (I usually get them 2,000 @ a time for about $6 each shot) I still only pay about $130 a year for a smartphone!Some people I have talked to pay near that price for 1 month
I think that is CRAZY
You can also go on a plan through Tracfone for $20 a month which only limits your data- and wifi is everywhere, so why do it- it might be worth it if you call and text a lot- that comes to $240
It is larger (6
5 inch screen) and has a better outward shooting camera (13 vs 8 megapixel
Budget minds get a phone that makes sense!
I use my phone daily to check email, send a few text messages and occassionaly talk to friends and family
I use hey google a lot to look-up all kinds of things and to dictate my text messages
If you don't need expensive, then give this phone a try
Great phone for the kids....!
Bought two of these for my kids as it was time to get them cellphones
Got each for $40 bucks on sale and each phone has a $16 per month plan
So for and $80 dollar investment and $32 per month in phone bills, both my kids now have dependable, nice phones to use with unlimited texts and calling
Have not had one problem with them
Other parents have even asked me how I did this because they want to get their kids set up with phones
Only down side is Nebraska as bad coverage if you live in that area
Most everywhere else is fine

Yesterday I spent the day working around the house
"Dream" Phone 2020

This is the best choice for a modern phone in 2020!It has great power-efficient specs, 90 Hz display, long-lasting battery, all-screen design (no notch!), very responsive fingerprint reader (for those who cannot use face unlock), minimum 3 years software support from Google (stock Android!) and 5G (for those who really want that)
It also has other features you would expect like USB-C and it supports all of those higher bitrate Bluetooth codecs like aptX and LDAC

Note that with the all-screen design, there are limited options for positioning the built-in speakers (not front facing), so there is one at the top under the display and the other one is on the bottom side
The speakers are plenty adequate although I use Bluetooth headphones a majority of the time with phone calls, listening to music, or really anything
Display Issues and Data Issues

The good:Feels nice to holdBattery lasts a long timeSoftware is stable (mostly)Camera features are greatThe Bad:Display was separating from the enclosure on the left side (out of box)Using Google Fi service I got no Data and spent 2 days with Google support trying to fix this issue

Fantastic so far!
My old Moto X Pure edition was starting to brick, all kinds of issues for the last 1-1/2 years
After research for months, it came down to the Samsung Galaxy S20 FE or the Pixel 5
While I'm sure I would have been happy with either one, certain features finally put this over the top for me
But both of these contribute to lower energy requirements and better battery life, which I knew going in
I just received this phone a few days ago, and it has been a HUGE step up from the Moto X Pure, which topped out on Android 7
0 and has not been supported for years
Now that I see how in the dark I'd been, technology-wise, I will be updating to a new phone before the current one becomes un-supported, and not try to nurse an old phone for as long as possible
It's just not worth it in the long run, considering OS and security updates, and the potential incompatibility with newer apps
My profile for context: mid-60's, not a power user / content streamer / social media consumer
I will likely upgrade to a Pixel XL if/when released in 4th quarter 2021 for easier reading of a larger display with older eyes
So IMO, if you are considering this phone, you will not be disappointed
If you get it, I recommend getting these with it: the Spigen Ultra Hybrid clear case, and the Anker PowerWave II wireless charging stand; both have been outstanding accessories so far
The Perfect Phone for Me
Main selling point for me is the one-handability
I much prefer the soft touch back over glass, as it's not fingerprint prone
The camera's ease-of-use is elegant, and the quality of photos is too notch
Connectivity and service supports modern WiFi and US bands
Screen brightness can get pretty bright
The bezels are the same size all the way around
Colors are vivid and accurate
Google's default/stock Android experience is the best Android experience and the easiest Android experience by far, so this is the best that is offered in terms of Android phones in my experience
The chip is older, but this is intentional
Other phones to consider: The thumbprint of the Pixel 4A is nearly identical to the Pixel 5, except with slightly thinner bezels, making a larger screen
Had audio problems with my first phone, but the replacement works fine.
Updated on 1/29/2021:I returned my original phone through Amazon (which they did without complaint), and tried a different Pixel 5
The audio in it is much better than my original phone
I'm not sure what this means about audio quality on average with Pixel 5's, but I'm fully satisfied with my replacement phone
This resolved my only real issue wit the Pixel 5
I've changed my rating from 2 to 5 stars
When I say poor audio, I mean: very weak and distorted sound at mid-volume, almost no volume increase but much more distortion at max volume
It's very hard to use the phone in an environment with any noise because it's just too hard to hear
My old Pixel 2 XL sounds fantastic by comparison
Google Support said audio should be fine, and walked me though software tweaks - things like turning off Bluetooth and switching between wifi and cellular data
They then had me boot to safe mode, which deleted all of my widgets and turned off other customizations like an alternative keyboard that I use
I had to manually restore these after leaving safe mode
Next step was to backup my phone and factory reset it, which lost me some of my most recent texts even though I backed up after receiving them
After all that, Google Support suggested I contact a warranty repair shop on a phone that I took out of the box for the first time 3 days ago
The phone is sleek, has a nice display, good camera and great battery life; but it's a crummy phone
I can't give it more than 2 stars
Google Support deserves 0 stars
Don't worry about the processor. Huge upgrade over pixel 2.
Aside from Amazon sending me the sage one instead of black, like I ordered, this phone is better than expected
It's very fast, display is amazing and it multitasks better than my pixel 2 due to having 2wice the memory
My best smartphone upgrade ever - from Pixel 3 to Pixel 5
I was quite happy with my Pixel 3 until recently its battery drained like crazy
Excellent, attractive, well rounded phone.  Reported "issues" maybe overblown.
Great phone
Really enjoying my first week with it

NON-ISSUES (FOR ME):I had a few concerns going in which turned out to be non-issues for me:1) Gap between screen and body: There were many reports online of an inconsistent gap between the screen and aluminum body of the phone, with an especially large gap near the corner with the camera
Maybe I got lucky, but did not have this issue
There's a VERY small gap on my phone, but it's consistent all the way around, appears to be by design, and doesn't bother me at all
While I do notice the lack of stereo sound on the Pixel 5, I found the overall volume and clarity of the Pixel 5 to be better actually
Does it compete with the best phones out there in terms of sound?Probably not
But for my purposes it is more than adequate
I also found the behind-screen speaker for phone calls to be fine
It's a little weird for the whole phone to vibrate when someone's talking, but I've already gotten used to it
It's not going to compete with an iPhone 12 Pro in all departments, but it's still good even though the main camera hardware is a couple years old
Wide-angle is nice to have
But for everyday tasks it's totally fine
Definitely faster and snappier than my Pixel 2, and the 90hz makes it all look buttery smooth
Not really missing this feature as much as I thought I would
MINOR CONS:1) The bio-resin on edges near the screen seems a little rough, and the cutout for the USB-C port could have been rounded a bit so the edge wasn't so sharp
Neither seem like defects, but I used to use my pinky as a ledge to sit the phone on, and now that's a little uncomfortable
Just an adjustment I'll need to make
I don't use a case, so if you're planning on using one this issue will be moot for you
In normal use this is not an issue, but it it's not quite as good as an iPhone XS or 11
I've never had one so I don't know what I'm missing
I think I have more use for wide-angle so it's an ok tradeoff for me, but it would have been nice to have telephoto too
If you have a Pixel 4 and use the telephoto a lot, this might not be the upgrade path for you
You still end up with black bars at the top and bottom in most cases behind the notification area at the top and the gesture line at the bottom
They should really be transparent, especially at the bottom
Maybe that'll improve with time, but it's hard to actually appreciate the nice bezels on the phone on anything but the home screen
All in all, this is a 5-star phone for me
Looks great, and it's well rounded

Excellent Smartphone
I'm reluctant to pay this much for a smartphone as they're pretty much a consumable these days
That said, the Pixel 5 is a fantastic phone
The cell and WiFi radios outperform my Essential phone by a country mile
It will stay connected to our spotty WiFi better than any other phone or tablet I've owned
The pictures are nicely exposed and vibrant in any but the poorest conditions
It's a great size and weight for a smartphone
The screen looks rich and smooth as silk, but not oversaturated
The fingerprint sensor isn't as reliable as I'd like, and that it's surface looks like the texture on the rest of the back of the phone means that you can't glance at it to see if it's clean
And if it's to work, it needs to be really, really clean
The fit and finish is nice, and I didn't get an example with the half installed screen
I like the texture that's been applied to the body, even if it reminds me of Plastidip
The phone feels solid, but not overly weighty
It's sits in a jeans pocket nicely
Sits nicely in the hand, too
Just enough weight
Just enough
The GPS receiver appears to be quite a bit more sensitive than any previous phone of mine
It locks in on location fast, and in many places others never see the satellites
Wireless charging is, well, nice, if not the ultimate experience
Most of that is not an reflection of the phone
It's nice to be able to just lay the phone on a charger for the night
I switched to one that's a rounded rectangle, similar in size to the phone
Wireless charging is slow, of course, but the Pixel 5 will charge from 15% to full overnight
Speaking of charging, the Pixel 5 is relatively slow to charge when plugged into USB-C, but not to the point of being a real problem
Just don't expect to throw 50% charge on it while you're in the shower
I'm still learning the camera app, but it's more than good enough from what I've seen so far
Portrait Light would be useful on any subject, but Google only shows the control if they think the subject is human
Maybe it will develop enough over time to be used in any picture
I do recommend
The Android phone I wish I had all along
This is, without doubt, the best Android phone on the market
I've owned many devices, the latest of which was the top 256 GB/12 GB RAM OnePlus 7 Pro that frankly pales in comparison to the Pixel in almost every way
I appreciate that the phone also eschews many features I really don't care about or like, such as face unlock or those godforsaken abysmal in-display fingerprint sensors
It's not perfect; the camera punch-out makes the status bar pretty chunky and I'd prefer it to be centered since by default, Android doesn't display anything there
Perhaps my biggest gripe is that I purchased it for Google Fi, but I don't get reception anywhere I should be able to as network switching doesn't seem to be working correctly
I'm extremely pleased with this phone
After freaking out for a bit, it's the best phone experience

I switched from a Galaxy S20 because I couldn't stand the bloatware and all the apps you can't delete anymore, plus with the Android 11 update the google photos app became really annoying with a bunch of permission dialogs
This was a great idea, the OS is really clean and it runs really fast even with the 765G processor
I thought the battery life would be the same but it is also much better and, this may be a matter of taste, but I even like the camera more in some situations, which takes us to the scary part
The main sensor was taking really blurry pictures while the ultra wide sensor worked well, I attached 2 pictures, one with each sensor, to show how bad it was
Thankfully I followed this steps and it fixed the issue:Clear the camera app data
Uninstall the updates (just hit uninstall on the Play Store, it will only uninstall the update)Force stop the Camera appUpdate the Camera app againRestart the phoneAfter that everything works amazing
The 90Hz display also looks great, can't really tell the difference between it and the 120Hz
I'll update my review if anything happens, but for now, this phone is a keeper

x vs Andorid OS 8
I never took my old phone up to Android 9
x for fear they would screw it up
I am glad to report that my fears were unwarranted
From what I have observed in OS 11
x there are basically a finer granularity of control over app phone access and battery usage

For example I had one add that after loading it saw my battery life get chopped in half but after going it and telling the phone to only allow the app to run when it was active on the main screen my battery life was restored
This type of control is a welcome feature and not a detriment
The new version of bluetooth seems to work very well connecting to multiple different bluetooth devices and the control is exceptional
I am able to go into each BT device and select the level of phone access I want it to have
as an example I want my phone to only interface with the BT in my Auto for media playback and not phone calls or contacts
There are simply on/off sliders for this level of access
Just to be clear if you are a media heavy user this review is probably only of limited use as I don't watch youtube video's or watch tv shows/movies on my phone

I Was An iPhone User For The Last Decade
I have used iPhones for the last decade, so this is my first foray into Android phones
The Pixel 5 seems to be agood option for an Android phone
I was intrigued by this phone because it seemed to have many options found on more expensive phones, but at a lower price point
So far, I am pleased with its performance and capabilities
As with anything new, it takes a little getting used to, but it is very comparable to the iPhone in its operation
The kit comes with the phone, a charge cord and block, a quick switch iPhone adapter, and a manual
The screen size is taller than my previous iPhone, but it is not as wide
While I would prefer a wider screen, it will do
I would also prefer if the app icons were larger
Despite adjusting the display to maximum size, they are still small
My prior phone would display four icons in each row, but the Pixel displays five
More icons on a smaller width screen makes it difficult for my aging eyes to find what I need quickly
I would also prefer if the home screen did not have such a large day and date display
It takes up so much room that you lose an entire row of app icons
Subsequent screens do not have that display, so you regain a row of icons
This phone has a fingerprint reader on the back, but it does not have face recognition technology
I do not need face recognition, so this is not a problem for me
I was concerned with how I was going to set up a non-iPhone without losing data or having to put in a great amount of effort to get my apps and data transferred
In reality, the setup was fairly painless
I was surprised to find that I could connect the two phones together using the included quick switch adapter and transfer almost everything over
After turning on the Pixel, I went through the initial setup options (language, WiFi, etc
The setup process then took me through the normal phone setup options such as backup options, location sharing, etc
All of my contacts, calendar items, photos, notes, messages, and many device settings copied over perfectly
For an unknown reason, only 74 of my 137 apps were transferred to the new phone
I assume that the Pixel looks for matching apps in Google Play and, if a match is found, installs the app from there
Most of the apps that were not copied over had a match in Google Play, so I am not certain why they didn't transfer
Am I unhappy that I had to manually load some apps?No!I was quite pleased that the Pixel was able to copy over what it did from my iPhone without having to go to great lengths to load the data
I am only beginning to explore the Pixel 5 but there are a few features that I really like
This phone is not only Qi wireless charging capable, but it also offers reverse wireless charging, which allows the Pixel to charge other phones that have wireless charging capabilities
I was able to charge an iPhone using the Pixel
To accomplish this, you just need to place the two phones back-to-back and the second phone will start charging
Of course,you will consume the Pixel’s charge while doing this
I like the camera’s capabilities
Google is known for having good photo capability and performance, and it shows in the quality of the photos and videos that I have taken
I like the 360 degree panorama and the photosphere capabilities
The photosphere pictures are created by taking a series of photos in a 360 degree up and down, and side to side, manner and the Pixel 5 stitches them together to form an interactive 3D image
The camera also has several options for camera stabilization when shooting videos
These options are set depending on the expected movement of the camera, the subject, or both
This option works well when, for example, I shoot a video while walking
I like that the camera has an ultrawide lens capability
I have often had to use the panorama mode to get everything in a picture that I wanted, but the wide-angle capability eliminates that in many situations
The overall speed and responsiveness of this phone is good
The apps load quickly, and there is no hesitancy in their operation
I installed a premium screen protector, and I have not experienced any issues with the touch screen's operation
The battery lasts a long time, which I definitely appreciate
Camera Does Not Disappoint
This was my first experience with the Pixel line of phones
I am Android person but pretty much the rest of my family swings in the Apple direction
As I step further and further in the busy world of being a mom of two teens and a toddler I find myself trying to streamline more things
The most recent edition is my camera
I love taking pictures of my kids
I spend so much time worrying about bring the right camera and accessories with me because I am always afraid I won't have a great way to capture a moment
I know a lot of people use their normal cell phone cameras to take pictures but I just couldn't
I had a friend tell me about the Pixel line of phones and how great their on board cameras were
She told me that I could probably use the phone camera and get amazing shots of our everyday adventures
I was pretty skeptical but I really needed a way to not have to lug around the giant camera when we were just going to the park for the afternoon
The Pixel camera is amazing
First I couldn't believe how great the picture quality was
It is just as nice as the main camera I was using for those everyday photos
I don't take selfies very often but I have had a ton of fun playing with the lighting on the selfie mode
Adjusting where the lighting was after the photo really gives new life to some of the pictures I took
Now lets talk about the battery life
My life is on my cell phone
I use it for everything so it is nothing for me to have to charge my phone at least once and sometimes twice per day
With the Pixel I might be in single digits by the time I go to bed but I haven't had to charge it during the middle of the day

Not having to remember to bring my cord with me everywhere I go is such a nice change from how I have been operating that feature alone has sold me on being a Pixel person now!As I mentioned before I am an Android person
I have used an version of an Android phone for years and so I know how the operating system works and what I can generally expect
I am very pleased to say that the Pixel has been practically flawless to operate
Google really did work out all the kinks on previous models before they got to the 5
The phone works smoothly and has a very streamlined experience
The only downside
Meaning that standard USB outlets on your computer, wall jacks, cigarette lighter adapters, jump chargers and so on won't be compatible with this cord without an adapter piece

With all of the devices that are transitioning to USB-C I don't think this will be an issue for much longer but presently you will either need to be using the power brick or an adapter when charging your phone
Again this really isn't a major issue but something you should know
Overall as a long time Android user I am very pleased with the features of this Google Pixel 5 and I can't say enough good things about the camera and picture quality
BEST PIXEL PHONE YET, no screen gap, switching over from OnePlus 7 Pro
I think a lot of people think the best phone is the phone that has the largest/biggest/fastest everything
The camera hardware is a few generations old but it's the software that does the heavy lifting these days

The end result is a phone that prioritizes the features most users want first, such as all day battery life, top in class picture quality, 5G connectivity and a speedy interface with the latest OS features and updates
My phone did not have the screen gap issue as reported by some users
The Google Pixel 4a 5G is a great alternative and a better buy at $150 less if you can live without the waterproofing, wireless charging and 2GB less RAM
What's not to like?
If you're like me, and you don't want a phone the size of your head, there's really not much to choose from
Other reviews cover things nicely, but I want to add 2 things
I also want to address something else that was important to me, security
In this case, true it's Google, but it in fact comes with the least amount of bloatware or added trackers of any other Android phone (can't speak for Apple)
So fear not, if security is a concern, I know it's kind of hard to believe, but Pixel really is one of your best bets when it comes to flagship devices
Throw on everything else, namely the camera, battery, and screen size

Love this upgrade!

There's so much wrong with this phone
-Volume control only controls media volume and not ringtone or notification volume
-Aforementioned volume problem means that you cannot silence any incomings notifications when you're on the phone
-Googling anything takes you to a page with recommended results instead of a website results page

-If you are playing music through any app via Bluetooth and pause the music, or turn your car off when it was connected, the music will sometimes start playing at full blast a minute later even if you've closed the app
-The screen brightness adjusts itself, even when the auto-adjust is turned off
-No ability to categorize or group contacts together for texting
-No pin to screen capability
-The Sega Dreamcast had more customizable settings
-Awful camera software
-Vibration is undetectable

I still believe
My very first Google phone was the OG Pixel back in 2017
Then Big Tech decided headphone jacks weren't necessary for top-tier phones, so I avoided upgrading my phone for as long as I could
But deep down, I missed Pixel
The Pixel 5 has everything I love about the OG Pixel but better
And although the processing speeds are better, they could definitely be improved

I cannot review anything about 5G as I am on Metro by T-Mobile, so speeds and such are already on the low end, but if you cannot get good 5G coverage/don't think it's necessary yet, I would recommend checking out Pixel 4a (which has a headphone jack, if that's important to you)
Although Google Pixel now has two product lines, and maybe the mid-tier Pixels are better for the money, I still want to believe in the original Pixel
Definite improvement over the pixel 4a
It a great phone, specially if you are an Android fan
The phone itself looks good and the build quality is solid
I don't particularly liked the round camera notch on the left but, though small, it feels like it's stuck there unintentionally
The OELD display is pretty sweet with a slight decrease in ppi from the 4a (432 to 443) bit the screen is larger which also makes it slightly more heavy
Other improvements are the better battery, ram, processor, water resistance and reverse wireless charging
The OS is fluid and the touch controls are smooth

Overall it's a good device from Google with a reasonable flagship price compare to the competitors flagships phones, though its is slightly simpler looking one it would make sense for a lot of people who wants the latest tech without the extra premium
"Painted?" Slippery Slope
I've been a Pixel/Nexus user for years
Coming from a Pixel 1, which is still a solid phone that's decently fast given its age
Also still using the Pixel C tablet
Before this was planing on going with the Pixel 4a but the 4a's kept restarting when plugged into my car charger, so tried the Pixel 5
Have tried both the Black and the Green color of Pixel 5
The Green one was heating up a bit so got the black one as a replacement which also seems to get warm
The texture feeling is very different between the two colors
The black one is much rougher texture, but maybe I got a weird one
The texture makes it more grippy, which is good, but it's painted or somehow applied onto the metal body
In my experience when things are painted on they don't hold up as well
Reminds me of the term slippery slope
Slopes are slippery apparently
At least it has some grip texture
I'm not a big fan of the hardware and design, same with the Pixel 1, and have doubts about their quality control
But Pixel software experience is highly rated in the Android world

You get updates frequently and longer than many other Android phones, get some great Google features that other phones may not have, get not much bloat ware, and get one of the best rated phone cameras (software enhanced)
The fact that almost the whole phone is a screen is a big plus coming from phones with bezels
Can see more and put more apps on home screen
Top speaker is behind the screen
Was worried it might be too weak sounding but sound for my device is very loud
Has large battery and battery life is very good
That's one of it's best features
Also seems to have lots of ram
Not sure what all the buzz is about with 90htz display
Don't seem to matter for me as much

Price seemed high for my taste, when you can get the Pixel 4a which has so many good things for half the price, and is going to receive updates for about as long if I understand, with same amount of storage, great screen, decent battery life, if it doesn't restart on you
ok phone but could be better. they should focus on basics, not nonsense.
